III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• The facility was offered technical assistance regarding date of hire as one
file had two different dates of hire causing the employees evaluation date
to be off. Discussed using a consistent method to determine date of hire.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facilities current variance for an interim supervisor while the facility
continues to attempt to hire a candidate that meets the rule requirements.
2

• The facility provides leadership training opportunities for management as
during staff interview concerns were shared regarding leadership style.
• The facility continues to face challenges with dentals due to the lack of
dental providers in the area. Discussed the facility continuing to document
all efforts made to get youth scheduled for regular appointments and as
needed appointments. The facility continues to use the Wheels program
when available.
• Discussed concerns verbalized by staff and ways to boost staff moral and
show staff appreciation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
Renewal 2024: Corrective Action Plan was recorded during this reporting period
as a result of the Renewal Inspection completed on 10/1/2024. This CAP
contained rule violations of CCI Rule 400.4111 in that employee files were lacking
job descriptions, CCI Rule 400.4113 in that employee file lacked verification of
education, CCI Rule 400.4114 in that employee files lacked tuberculosis testing,
CCI Rule 400.4155 and 400.4156 in that initial treatment plan and updated
treatment plans lacked input from parents, staff, and referral worker, and CCI Rule
400.4156 in that an initial treatment plan lacked signatures and date. The CAP
contained action items to ensure all documentations required prior to hire were in
the employee file prior to the official offer of employment being made and
implemented action steps of the social service supervisor reviewing and meeting
with social service worker to address the rule violations found regarding treatment
plans. The CAP was effective as the facility had no repeat violations during this
interim inspection.
• Special Investigation 2025SIC0000042 with CAP approval date of 11/21/2024
was a result of a violation regarding the facility not following their internal
supervision policy. The facility retrained staff and facility implemented camera
reviews to ensure staff were properly supervising youth. The CAP was effective
as the facility has had no concerns at this time regarding supervision and the CAP
monitoring period has ended.
• Special Investigation 2025SIC0000564 with CAP approval date of 6/3/2025 was
a result of the facility not following their internal religious policy and staff not
3

receiving annual verbal de-escalation training. The facility updated their internal
religion policy, trained staff on the updated religion policy, and discussed the
religion policy at team meetings. The facility retrained staff on verbal de-escalation
training and professionalism as well as implemented a training log system which
the trainer uses in order to schedule staff coming due for required trainings. The
agency is currently complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to
monitor CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Financial Overview
The facilities financial audit was reviewed by Michigan Department of Health &
Human Services Bureau of Audit due to concerns noted in past audit findings. The
organization continues to have a decline in total net assets and a negative working
capital. There were repeated findings for the 2022 and 2023 audit. Corrective
measures will be requested and required to mitigate the finding by the Bureau of
Audit as the facility continues to not have staffing to complete the accounting
functions including segregation of duties. The facility’s corrective measures
indicated the Board of Directors would be involved in the day-to-day accounting
process so that one individual is not responsible for three transaction components,
authorization, custody, and recordkeeping. It appears the Board of Directors have
not been involved in this process and the facility is not following their corrective
measures. The organization’s financial condition will continue to be monitored.
Although there are continuing concerns regarding finances, this has not affected
the care of the youth at the facility.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. Chief administrator reported
previous CAP action steps assisted the facility to implement new proactive
processes to ensure compliance regarding employee files. Chief Administrator
found having both the Human Resource Coordinator and Training Coordinator
review employee files prior to scheduling new employees for training has ensured
all requirements are obtained and the facility is in compliance. The Social Service
Supervisor has worked with Social Service Workers regarding the importance of
obtaining family involvement in the treatment planning process and ensuring this is
documented in treatment plans. The facility continues to hire new employees and
is actively seeking out candidates. The facility continues to grow and improve on
processes, communication, and growing leadership.
Staff and Youth Interviews
4

Staff reported the youth are well cared for at the facility and all the youth's needs
are met. Two staff reported the facility is running well and communication continues
to be prioritized as an area of improvement. One staff reported some frustration
with communication and feeling as management does not always hear staff and
value staff's input and perspectives.
Youth interviews were conducted during the inspection. Youth reported being well
cared for at the facility. Youth reported staff met youth's needs. All youth report
feeling safe and supported at the facility and no concerns at this time.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An onsite inspection and walk through of the facility occurred on October 7, 2025.
There were no issues or safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. It is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
